channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Roma Poisoned at U.N. Camps in Kosovo May Get Apology and Compensation
item.description: A panel found that the United Nations compromised the lives and health of inhabitants of the camps, which were built on a toxic wasteland and had high levels of lead.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for the New York Times
item.media:description: A Roma boy living in a United Nations camp contaminated with lead in Kosovo in 2006. Hundreds of Roma families were forced to live in the camps.

item.title: Rattled by Outside Threats, Many Belgians Still Want Nation Split in Two
item.description: The Brussels attacks have shaken Belgium, but many are asking whether the Flemish north would be better off becoming its own country.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Self-styled “soccer hooligans” disturbed a peaceful rally outside the stock exchange in Brussels last month, at a shrine to victims of the March 22 terrorist attacks.

item.title: Panama Papers Continue to Shake Leaders Worldwide
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia dismissed the documents as an American plot, Iceland chose new leadership and Britain’s prime minister admitted to profiting from an offshore trust.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Dmitry Astakhov/Sputnik / Kremlin
item.media:description: From left, the cellist Sergei P. Roldugin, Vladimir V. Putin and Dmitry Medvedev at the House of Music in St. Petersburg in 2009.

item.title: European Union to Consider Requiring Visas for U.S. Travelers
item.description: The union is stepping up pressure on the United States to add more European countries to its list of those entitled to visa-free travel.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Dutch Referendum Rejects Trade Deal Between E.U. and Ukraine
item.description: In a nonbinding election, voters in the Netherlands said no to a trade and cooperation pact. All 28 member countries must approve the deal.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Republicans Seize on Guantánamo Fears in Re-election Races
item.description: With control of the Senate at stake, blue-state Republican incumbents hope the issue will let them reprise Scott Brown’s 2010 win in Massachusetts.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: A detainee paced around a cell block at Guantánamo Bay in Cuba last month.

item.title: Ernst Tremmel, Nazi War Crimes Suspect, Dies Days Before Trial
item.description: Mr. Tremmel, a 93-year-old former SS storm trooper who worked at Auschwitz, faced charges of complicity in the killings of at least 1,075 prisoners.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Reinhold Hanning, a former Nazi charged with being an accessory to the murder of at least 170,000 people at a concentration camp, arriving at a courthouse in Detmold, Germany, on Wednesday.

item.title: ISIS Abducts Workers From Cement Factory in Syria
item.description: If confirmed, the mass kidnapping reported by state media would punctuate the Islamic State’s penchant for brazen acts even in the face of recent defeats.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Kerry Confronts Concerns of Arab States After Iran Nuclear Deal
item.description: In Bahrain for a meeting of the Arab states this week, Secretary of State John Kerry found himself disputing arguments that Tehran was “as dangerous as ever.”
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Myanmar to Free Political Prisoners, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi Says
item.description: Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi, the country’s state counselor, said releasing the prisoners was the top priority of the new government.
item.dc:creator: SAW NANG and RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Panama Papers Leak Casts Light on a Law Firm Founded on Secrecy
item.description: Ramón Fonseca, a co-founder of Mossack Fonseca, proclaimed his firm’s innocence. But some say the leak’s contents are at odds with how he has tried to portray himself and his role in Panama.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE, AZAM AHMED and ERIC LIPTON
item.media:description: Panama City on Monday. The president of Panama has vowed to cooperate with investigations over a law firm’s leaked documents.

item.title: At Least 17 Civilians Killed in U.S. Airstrikes, Afghan Officials Say
item.description: Officials and elders in Paktika Province said 17 civilians were killed in American drone strikes, while a United States military spokesman said there was no evidence of such casualties.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: FAROOQ JAN MANGAL and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Belgian Police Release New Video of Brussels Airport Suspect
item.description: The footage provides a first look at how the “man in the hat” left the building right after the bombings, and where he went.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Solve the Nagorno-Karabakh Conflict Before It Explodes
item.description: The recent eruption of violence is a reminder that a dangerous conflict is smoldering in the South Caucasus. It has the potential to spread.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS DE WAAL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The West Is Enabling Graft in Ukraine
item.description: If you've gone to the trouble of stealing millions of dollars, you want to keep them somewhere more secure than Panama.
item.dc:creator: OLIVER BULLOUGH

item.title: Boko Haram Turns Female Captives Into Terrorists
item.description: Of all the many horrors of Boko Haram’s rampage, one of the most baffling has been its ability to turn captured women and girls into killers.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: Rahila Amos, a Nigerian grandmother, said she was abducted by Boko Haram and forced to take classes on how to carry out a suicide bombing.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Blaming Policy, Not Islam, for Belgium’s Radicalized Youth
item.description: For Yves Goldstein, a councilman in Brussels, allowing ethnic ghettos to grow unchallenged created the perfect recruiting ground for Islamists.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Schaerbeek neighborhood in Brussels. Salah Abdeslam, the Islamic State recruit who participated in the Paris terror attacks, sought refuge in the neighborhood for weeks.

item.title: Malaysia Panel Calls for Investigation of Former Head of 1MDB Fund
item.description: Members of the state investment fund’s board of directors said they would offer their resignation after a parliamentary committee released its report.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.media:description: The police seizing equipment from the office of 1Malaysia Development Berhad, the state investment fund, in Kuala Lumpur, the capital, last year.

item.title: Izmir Journal: Path to Greece Closed, Economy of Smugglers and Others Suffers in Turkey
item.description: Basmane Square in Izmir, its businesses and streets once teeming with migrants, has grown quiet since Greece has begun sending migrants back to Turkey.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: Migrants trying to negotiate with smugglers packed the area around the Sinbad restaurant in Basmane Square in Izmir, Turkey, in September. But this week, days after Greece began sending migrants back to Turkey under a contentious deal with the European Union, it was mostly empty.

item.title: As Graft Cases in Chile Multiply, a ‘Gag Law’ Angers Journalists
item.description: A new law would punish anyone who makes public information about current judicial investigations with up to 541 days in prison.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.media:description: Pablo Longueira, a former finance minister, in 2013, when he was a presidential candidate for the U.D.I. Party. Mr. Longueira resigned from his party last month.
